choices.text: Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats
Combines with the Cas nuclease
Cleave the DNA of invading phage
Provides no protection to the bacterium from phage infection

questions.text: A research team is studying bacterial resistance mechanisms against viral phage infections and focuses on the CRISPR system. In discussing its features, which of the following statements about CRISPR is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Provides no protection to the bacterium from phage infection  

 

Option D:

 

The false statement regarding CRISPR is that it "Offers no bacterial protection against phage" (d). CRISPR, along with associated Cas (CRISPR-associated) proteins, forms an adaptive immune system in bacteria and archaea, providing protection against invading genetic elements like phages by recognizing and cleaving their DNA, thereby preventing infection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Named for its sequence characteristics: True. The name CRISPR reflects the unique organization of short, partially palindromic repeated DNA sequences found in the genomes of bacteria and archaea.

 

Option B: Works in conjunction with Cas nuclease: True. The CRISPR system functions with Cas proteins, particularly the Cas nuclease, to identify and cut foreign DNA based on RNA sequences derived from previous invasions.

 

Option C: Can cleave invading phage DNA: True. The CRISPR-Cas system can specifically target and cleave DNA from invading phages, guided by RNA molecules that match the phage DNA sequences, providing a form of acquired immunity.


Educational Objective:

 

CRISPR/CAS system:

 

  • A prokaryotic immune system conferring resistance to external genes from bacteriophage.

  • This system provides a bacterial version of acquired immunity.

  • CRISPR (Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats) spacer derived RNA combines with the Cas nuclease to target and specifically cleave the DNA of invading phage, there by inactivating these invading genomes and protecting the bacterium from productive phage infection and lysis.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 461
